one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle‑aged woman with HIV off HAART and ESRD on hemodialysis presented after an extra dialysis session with exertional shortness of breath and symptomatic hypotension, likely from excessive ultrafiltration. In the ED she was briefly supported with vasopressors and a small fluid bolus, then admitted to the MICU, where her blood pressure quickly stabilized and her dyspnea resolved. Workup showed no acute cardiopulmonary process on chest X‑ray and CT angiography, and cardiology attributed a modest troponin T elevation with flat CK/CK‑MB and normal EKG to stress and renal disease rather than myocardial infarction. She remained on her thrice‑weekly hemodialysis schedule, with careful volume removal and continuation of cinacalcet, sevelamer (dose increased at discharge), and doxercalciferol. Evaluation of elevated LDH, new thrombocytopenia, and chronic cytopenias included abdominal ultrasound and serum studies, which demonstrated borderline splenomegaly, innumerable renal cysts, elevated beta‑2 microglobulin and immunoglobulins, and a polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia pattern without imaging evidence of lymphoma. Her HIV therapy was not restarted in‑hospital, but Pneumocystis and MAC prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim and azithromycin were continued. She remained afebrile with negative blood cultures, normotensive off pressors, and without recurrent dyspnea, and was discharged home ambulatory with assistance, to continue outpatient dialysis and follow up for HIV management and further evaluation of her hematologic abnormalities.

problem_list.status_at_discharge: Presented with blood pressure around 80/40 and symptoms of lightheadedness and weakness after an extra dialysis session intended to treat exertional dyspnea. She required brief vasopressor support and a small fluid bolus in the ED/MICU, with lactate initially elevated but improving. Infectious workup was negative, and her blood pressure stabilized to her baseline (~100 systolic) without ongoing pressors. At discharge she was normotensive on the ward, and the hypotension was attributed to excessive ultrafiltration during dialysis.

problem_list.problem: Shortness of breath of unclear etiology, resolved
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She reported several days of gradually worsening exertional dyspnea, which improved after the initial dialysis session but was followed by hypotension. Chest X‑ray showed no acute intrathoracic process, and CT angiography ruled out pulmonary embolism and parenchymal lung disease. Echocardiogram showed normal biventricular function with only mild mitral regurgitation and an atrial septal defect, and she was never hypoxic. Her dyspnea resolved during hospitalization and was thought to be related to volume overload prior to dialysis, with no recurrence by discharge.

She remained dialysis‑dependent and continued on a thrice‑weekly hemodialysis schedule during admission, with an extra session preceding presentation. Labs showed markedly elevated creatinine and BUN on arrival, improving after dialysis. She continued cinacalcet and sevelamer, with sevelamer dose increased at discharge, and received doxercalciferol and heparin with dialysis. She was discharged to continue outpatient hemodialysis via her existing right groin catheter.

Initial troponin T was elevated at 0.42 ng/mL with flat CK and CK‑MB and no ischemic changes on EKG. She denied chest pain, and cardiology felt this represented a mild stress troponin leak in the setting of hypotension and ESRD rather than acute myocardial infarction. Echocardiogram showed normal biventricular systolic function, mild mitral regurgitation, and an atrial septal defect without significant pulmonary hypertension. No further cardiac intervention was required, and she remained asymptomatic.

problem_list.problem: HIV infection off HAART with prophylaxis continued
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has longstanding HIV with a low CD4 count and prior PCP episodes and was not taking HAART at the time of admission. During hospitalization, she remained off antiretroviral therapy due to prior non‑adherence, with plans to restart under outpatient ID supervision. She continued Pneumocystis prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin, both of which were included in her discharge medications.

CBCs showed macrocytosis with hemoglobin around 9.8–10.6 g/dL, hematocrit in the low 30s, leukopenia with WBC 2.2–3.3 K/uL, and new thrombocytopenia with platelets around 107–109 K/uL. There was no evidence of acute bleeding, and counts remained stable without transfusion. The thrombocytopenia was suspected to be related to bone marrow suppression from active HIV, and outpatient follow‑up was recommended.

problem_list.problem: Elevated LDH and polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia with concern for lymphoma
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She was noted to have elevated LDH and, in the context of borderline calcium, eosinophilia, and new thrombocytopenia, underwent a malignancy workup. Abdominal ultrasound showed borderline splenomegaly (12.9 cm) with small likely hemangiomas and no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy. Serum studies revealed markedly elevated beta‑2 microglobulin, IgG, and IgM, and protein electrophoresis consistent with polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. No definitive evidence of lymphoma was found, and these abnormalities were flagged for outpatient follow‑up.

key_tests_and_results.result: Portable chest radiograph on admission showed well‑expanded, clear lungs with normal cardiomediastinal silhouette and no pleural effusion or pneumothorax, indicating no acute intrathoracic process.

CT angiogram of the chest demonstrated no evidence of pulmonary embolism or parenchymal lung disease. It showed stenosis of the left subclavian and bilateral brachiocephalic veins with a patent SVC and multiple thoracic collateral vessels, consistent with her history of difficult central venous access.

Initial troponin T was elevated at 0.42 ng/mL with CK 127 IU/L and CK‑MB 4 ng/mL, and EKG showed sinus rhythm with bigeminal PACs and no ischemic ST changes. Cardiology interpreted this as a mild stress troponin leak in the setting of hypotension and ESRD rather than acute myocardial infarction.

Abdominal ultrasound revealed borderline splenomegaly (12.9 cm, increased from prior), two small hyperechoic splenic foci likely hemangiomas, innumerable bilateral renal cysts without hydronephrosis, and no sonographic evidence of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

key_tests_and_results.test: Serum protein studies and beta‑2 microglobulin
key_tests_and_results.result: Serum studies showed markedly elevated beta‑2 microglobulin (72.4 mg/L), elevated IgG (1994 mg/dL) and IgM (710 mg/dL), and a protein electrophoresis pattern consistent with polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, suggesting broad immune activation rather than a monoclonal process.

key_tests_and_results.test: Complete blood counts and basic chemistries
key_tests_and_results.result: Serial labs showed macrocytic anemia (Hgb 9.8–11.8 g/dL, MCV 104 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.2–3.3 K/uL), and new thrombocytopenia (~107–109 K/uL). Kidney function tests were markedly abnormal at baseline (creatinine 8.6–9.9 mg/dL, BUN 69–94 mg/dL) with improvement after dialysis (creatinine 6.2 mg/dL, BUN 51 mg/dL). Potassium peaked at 7.1 mEq/L pre‑dialysis and normalized after treatment.

Transthoracic echocardiogram showed normal left and right ventricular size and systolic function (LVEF >55%), an atrial septal defect with early contrast passage to the left heart, mild mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology, and no pericardial effusion or significant pulmonary hypertension.
Blood cultures obtained during the hypotensive episode showed no growth, arguing against bacteremia as a cause of her shock.

treatments_and_meds.details: On presentation with blood pressure around 82/40 and symptoms of presyncope after an extra dialysis session, she received a small intravenous fluid bolus and brief vasopressor support in the ED/MICU. Her lactate was initially elevated but improved, and vasopressors were quickly weaned off as her blood pressure stabilized to her baseline without ongoing support.

Given hypotension and concern for possible sepsis, she received a single dose of vancomycin and piperacillin‑tazobactam in the ED. With negative infectious workup and rapid hemodynamic improvement, these antibiotics were not continued beyond the initial empiric therapy.

She continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis during admission, including a session to treat hyperkalemia (K 7.1 mEq/L) and volume status. Dialysis was performed via her right groin catheter with careful ultrafiltration to avoid recurrent hypotension. She received heparin for DVT prophylaxis, cinacalcet, sevelamer (dose increased at discharge), and intravenous doxercalciferol as part of her chronic ESRD regimen.

Because of her advanced HIV and low CD4 count, she was maintained on Pneumocystis prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin. These were continued during hospitalization and at discharge, while full HAART was deferred to outpatient infectious disease follow‑up due to prior non‑adherence.

In response to elevated LDH, new thrombocytopenia, and chronic cytopenias, she underwent an abdominal ultrasound and serum studies including beta‑2 microglobulin, immunoglobulin levels, and protein electrophoresis. Imaging showed borderline splenomegaly and no retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, while labs demonstrated elevated beta‑2 microglobulin, IgG, and IgM with a polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia pattern. No definitive lymphoma was identified, and outpatient follow‑up was arranged.

Her chronic pain and pruritus were managed with oxycodone‑acetaminophen as needed and hydroxyzine. She also received bowel regimen medications including docusate, senna, and bisacodyl to prevent constipation. These symptomatic treatments were continued or prescribed at discharge as appropriate.
